DataElement.preferredName: Tumor/Lesion Identification Supplemental Qualifiers Dataset Tumor Grade
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indication of the grade of a tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor/Lesion Identification Supplemental Qualifiers Dataset Tumor Grade
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the tumor/lesion identification domain.:The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the tumor/lesion identification domain.

Concepts.definition: A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the tumor/lesion identification domain.

Property.preferredDefinition: Describes how closely a cancer resembles normal tissue of its same type, and the cancer's probable rate of growth

Concepts.definition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: In the natural or normal place, confined to the site of origin without invasion of neighboring tissues.

Concepts.definition: In the natural or normal place, confined to the site of origin without invasion of neighboring tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail._Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.
Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost all of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread quickly and aggressively._The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost all of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread quickly and aggressively.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/8/22 added alt name of NA for CCTG cjl;

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
